name: Great Britain Alphabetically - Part C Quiz / Test | Geography | 10 Questions

questions.text: According to legend, Lady Godiva famously rode naked through the streets of which city?
questions.explanation:
Coventry.

	The centre of Coventry was devastated by a bombing raid on November 14th, 1940; the city was almost completely rebuilt, the most famous new building being the cathedral designed by Sir Basil Spence.

questions.text: Which town in the English Midlands is famous for the crooked spire of the St Mary and All Saints Church?
questions.explanation:
Chesterfield.

	The church was built in the 14th century, and it is believed that the heat of the sun expanded the lead plates in the spire, warping the wooden frame into its twisted shape.

questions.text: Which British city is home to the 74,500 capacity Millennium Stadium, site of international soccer and rugby matches?
questions.explanation:
Cardiff.

	Cardiff has been the capital of Wales since 1955.

questions.text: Which English city was known by the Romans as Deva, and contains a racecourse called the Roodee within the ancient city walls?
questions.explanation:
Chester.

	Chester is the county town of Cheshire.

questions.text: Which city has a university that was founded in 1209 by students from Oxford who fled hostile townspeople?
questions.explanation:
Cambridge.

	Cambridge University today consists of 31 different colleges.

questions.text: Which seaport is home to Osborne House, where Queen Victoria spent much of the last 40 years of her life?
questions.explanation:
Cowes.

	Cowes, on the Isle of Wight, is today famous for its sailing regattas.

questions.text: Which town is the oldest in England, known to the Romans as Camulodunum?
questions.explanation:
Colchester.

	Camulodunum was capital of Roman Britain until AD 61. Nowadays, Colchester is home to the University of Essex.

questions.text: Which Scottish town is a popular tourist stop for visitors to The Trossachs, and was the real-life setting of Tannochbrae in the TV series Dr Finlay's Casebook?
questions.explanation:
Callander.

	Callander is also associated with the famous outlaw Rob Roy MacGregor, who lived in nearby Balquhidder.

questions.text: Which English city is the site of a cathedral in which Archbishop Thomas Becket was murdered in 1170?
questions.explanation:
Canterbury.

	The Archbishop of Canterbury is the spiritual leader and senior clergyman of the Church of England.

questions.text: Which Gloucestershire town has a famous National Hunt racing festival each March?
questions.explanation:
Cheltenham.

	The Cheltenham Gold Cup is one of the most prestigious races in the British horse-racing calendar.
